procedure: Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair, left shoulder
extraction_data.summary: 45-year-old female presented with progressive shoulder pain and weakness following a workplace fall. Diagnostic arthroscopy revealed a full-thickness supraspinatus tear and superior labral instability from 11 to 1 o'clock position. Treatment included arthroscopic rotator cuff repair using four anchors and labral repair with two knotless anchors. Patient was discharged in stable condition with an arm immobilizer and outpatient pain management plan.

primary_reasons: No documentation of function-limiting pain
No documentation of failure of non-surgical management for at least 3 months
No documentation of advanced diagnostic imaging study results
No documentation of physical examination findings

requirement_checklist.suggestion: Document evaluation and exclusion of other potential causes of shoulder pain

documentation: Function-limiting pain for at least six (6) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L156-L157)
Abnormal shoulder physical examination findings compared to non-involved side including functionally limited range of motion or measurable loss in strength (Evidence: pg no: 4, L158-L161)
Positive Neer Impingement Test or Hawkins-Kennedy Impingement Test (Evidence: pg no: 4, L162)
Failure of provider-directed non-surgical management for at least three (3) months in duration (Evidence: pg no: 4, L163-L164)
Advanced diagnostic imaging study (e.g., MRI, CT) is inconclusive for internal derangement/pathology (Evidence: pg no: 4, L165)

Other potential pathological conditions have been excluded including fracture, thoracic outlet syndrome, brachial plexus disorders, referred neck pain and advanced glenohumeral osteoarthritis (Evidence: pg no: 4, L166-L168)

exclusions: Any other indication or condition (Evidence: pg no: 5, L171-L172)
In-office diagnostic arthroscopy (e.g., Mi-Eye™, VisionScope®) - considered experimental, investigational, or unproven (Evidence: pg no: 5, L175-L176)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)

full_source.description: Shoulder hemiarthroplasty (partial replacement) may be used to address isolated humeral head pathology (avascular necrosis), some fractures, or as an option for rotator cuff tear arthropathy. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L176-L177)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). documentation: Proximal humerus fracture not amenable to internal fixation (Evidence: pg no: 9, L291)
Malignancy involving the glenohumeral joint or surrounding soft tissue (Evidence: pg no: 10, L293)
Advanced joint disease of the shoulder when criteria for total shoulder arthroplasty are met AND at least ONE of the following conditions is present (Evidence: pg no: 10, L294-L295)

exclusions: Total shoulder arthroplasty or hemiarthroplasty under conditions which would result in excessive stress on the implant including, but not limited to, Charcot joint and paralytic conditions of the shoulder (Evidence: pg no: 11, L332-L333)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, glenohumeral joint; hemiarthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 11, L363)

full_source.notes: Specific conditions include osteonecrosis of the humeral head without glenoid involvement, advanced joint disease due to rotator cuff tear arthropathy, glenoid bone stock inadequate to support a glenoid prosthesis, and glenohumeral osteoarthritis with irreparable rotator cuff tear. (Evidence: pg no: 10, L296-L299)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). InSpace Biodegradable Subacromial Spacer (Evidence: pg no: 5, L254)
full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Olivia Martin
MRN: 452198765
Date of Service: October 22, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Aiden Patel, MD

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Arthroscopic rotator cuff repair, left shoulder
2. Arthroscopic labral repair, left shoulder

INDICATIONS:
45-year-old female with progressive shoulder pain and weakness. Clinical exam and imaging suggested combined rotator cuff and superior labral pathology after a workplace fall.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Symptomatic rotator cuff tear, left shoulder
2. Superior labral tear, left shoulder

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
The patient was brought to the operating room and positioned in modified beach chair. After routine preparation and draping, standard posterior viewing portal was established with an anterior working portal.

DIAGNOSTIC ARTHROSCOPY:
Global inspection revealed fraying of the superior labrum with instability at the 11 to 1 o'clock position. A full-thickness tear involving the supraspinatus was visualized. Biceps anchor appeared intact.

LABRAL REPAIR:
Unstable labral tissue was lightly debrided. Knotless anchors were used to reapproximate the labrum to the glenoid rim with stable fixation.

ROTATOR CUFF REPAIR:
Attention was directed to the supraspinatus tear. The footprint was cleared of soft tissue and prepared for repair. Two medial row anchors were placed with lateral row fixation to restore footprint coverage.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Arm immobilizer applied in the operating room. Outpatient pain regimen and sling instructions provided. Physical therapy protocol to be determined at first postoperative visit.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Not documented.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.

IMPLANTS:
Two knotless labral anchors and four rotator cuff anchors placed.

DISPOSITION:
Transferred to PACU in stable condition.
